title: Do wireless Bluetooth headphones cause cancer? - Quora

response.answer_text: There're two ways to look at this: Evidence-based medicine and science-based medicine.  In evidence-based medicine, we take something, test it on groups of people with appropriate double-blind, control groups, sample size, etc. then we see if there's a correlation. For example, we could randomly give 100 people a set of headphone without them knowing if they are connected to bluetooth or not, follow them for the 20 years and see if one group has a higher cancer occurrence than the other. That would suggest "bluetooth headphones are correlated with cancer" but it would not tell us why in any way. For all we know, there could be no causation whatsoever. Of those types of study that have been done, there has been no correlation in between bluetooth device (or wifi, or radio waves, or high power electricity lines...) and cancer. It doesn't mean no correlation will ever be found, we just haven't done the studies yet. In science-based medicine, we first ask yourself "how could bluetooth device ever cause cancer ?" I mean, if there's a causation relationship, there better be some physical/chemical way this is happening. We know that any electro-magnetic wave with energy lower than ultra-violet cannot cause cancer because the photons don't have enough energy to ionize an electron. To cause a DNA mutation, we need at least one photon to ionize one electron in one atom of a cell's DNA. Actually, we need a lot more than one photon to do that because normally, the cell is very good at getting rid of bad DNA. We would need the ionizing photons to cause so much trouble that it overwhelms the cells and a tumor starts to form.  Most people actually know that already. UV light from the sun causes... skin cancer ! That's why you should wear sunscreen ! Too much X-ray exposure is bad because... it can cause cancer ! That's why X-ray technicians leave the room before a scan ! There would be no life on earth if we were exposed to the gamma rays from space... because all DNA would be corrupted all the time and nothing could survive !  Now think about it the other way. What has just a bit less energy than UV light ? Well, visible light. Have you heard of people being afraid of green light or yellow light because it might cause cancer ? Do we hear recommendations about turning off the lights and only come out at night because visible light causes cancer ? Of course not. Well, all the other types of EM waves have even less energy than the visible light, so even less chances to cause cancer. That includes infra-red light, microwaves and radio waves. That includes bluetooth signal, and wifi, and cellphone communication, and all of those types of things.  So in science-based medicine we would say "there's no possible mechanism for bluetooth waves to ionize an electron and corrupt DNA, thus there's no possible ways for those waves to cause cancer. There is thus no point at investigating this matter further. If bluetooth users all eventually get cancer, maybe the paint is bad, maybe their lifestyle is bad, maybe having cancer makes people more likely to use bluetooth devices".  My take is : bluetooth devices won't give you brain cancer.

Hi.. Looks like you’ve sparked quite an interest in the subject. Electromagnetic waves RF have been around us for many. many years. I assume we will continue to let the ship sail as it does until we hit the rocks near the shore. So, Is there enough RF energy in our wireless toys to cause, health issues…I found a couple of articles, that suggest animal studies, have shown the RF has effected animal health, but not in humans. To be truthful, I don’t know what that means. I kinda wonder if exposure and intensity is a random factor from person to person. Small mice might be more sensitive, to exposure than a 200-pound person might be. Kinda like, I can have, say 2 beers and feel fine…give 2 beers to someone half my size, and they may act differently. Anyway, here is the article..I’m confident, as soon as a study is completed, and exposure limits are set, notices will be release, recalls will occur, CNN will probably blow up on this..etc..here are the articles….. “Wireless technologies are simply outpacing both research and regulation – and it could have disastrous effects on our health. […] While the scientific jury is still out on whether or not particular devices cause cancer, animal studies on the kind of radiofrequency radiation that they emit – which is used in Bluetooth, cellular and wifi transmissions – has suggested a link to cancer.” “To date, the current scientific consensus is that there is little to no evidence that RF causes an increased risk of cancer in humans. While experimental studies in animals have shown an increased incidence of certain tumors such as heart schwannomas upon prolonged exposure to RF, their relevance to humans is in question, as discussed later in the article.” Almost scary when you think about it.. Be Safe Dave

Maybe. If you are extremely prone to cancer (family history) to begin with. Wireless and Bluetooth products have (for the most part) been tested (or at least “qualified” based on their frequency ranges and power levels). So apparently the FCC doesn’t think so. However, their acceptance is probably based on “typical” exposure times. So qualified by exposure limits, a few hours a day shouldn’t be problematic, but if you wear them 24/7/365 you may have a realistic concern. Same goes for cell phones. But hey, it’s 2019. All of us are continually beamed 24/7/365 with various signals from TV stations, Radio stations, Cell phone towers, Cell phones, CB radios, Police radios, Police radar, Military radios, Military radar, Satellite signals, NASA communications, and Microwave ovens. Not to mention nuclear radiation from military tests and power plant accidents, radon and other naturally occurring radioactive mineral radiations, Sun spot radiation, typical background Solar radiation, and various types of Deep space radiation. It’s all out there 24/7/365. You simply can’t avoid it. It’s literally a “soup” of all kinds of different types, frequencies and power levels. You’d have to wear a lead lined suit 24/7/365 to avoid it all. Then you’d need to worry about lead exposure. Then you’d need to worry about worrying because of stress related illnesses and cancers… It all snowballs! Where does it end? And they say people with “tin foil hats” are crazy… Crazy like a fox!

Firstly, if there is a risk, it is likely to be relatively small: although artificially produced radio waves ---such as those emitted by Bluetooth devices--- have a somewhat long history now, no association has been found between exposure and occurrence of cancer. However, contrary to what Lapierre-Landry claimed, currently there is no way science could refute the possibility of any adverse effects with a high degree of confidence.  Unlike visible light, radio waves can penetrate the skin, and although they are fairly unreactive, hypothetically speaking, chronic exposure could certainly have non-negligible effects. For example, many biochemical reactions depend on the formation of highly reactive intermediates that could potentially respond to small inputs of energy ---such as from photons in radio waves--- and although the possibility that exposure to radio waves could lead to the formation of unique species seems exceedingly low, long-term exposure could perhaps affect the concentrations of pre-existing ones by slightly accelerating reactions in specific directions, and thereby possibly affect cellular signaling or other things that could contribute to carcinogenesis. The same argument could be used for the reverse hypothesis, to support the idea that Bluetooth radiation could, by some unknown mechanism, be healthy. If you want to be as prudent as possible, I would suggest that you stay updated on this subject, read studies ---not just the results, but the complete papers--- and decide for yourself, instead of trusting individual scientists too much.

Most of the people use device radiation as a reason of cancer formation therefore it is a common misconception that using wireless Bluetooth headphone can cause brain cancer. There are definitely harmful radiations in devices like smartphone and laptop but this is also the fact that needs to be understood that there are no harmful radiations in headphone. Since headphone does not emit radiation, it can never become the reason of brain cancer. Another aspect that people connect with the headphone is headache. People say that regular use of headphone can cause headphone. Well, I am a person who uses headphone every day for personal as well as business purpose. And of course, there is no such thing as headache in my experience. Let me explain the reason behind headache that people face due to regular use of headphones.According to my experience, headache is caused only when you are listening to a high volume music or audio or when you are concentrating on computer too much.Either way, it is not exactly right to connect any kind of disease or discomfort directly with the use of headphone because that is not the truth. According to the facts, headphone doesn't have any harmful radiation at all so they can only cause discomfort if you are not used to it.

Well no and yes, BT headphones create a SWR (Short Wavelength Radiation) and is always emitting it (as long as it's on). Cellphones also emits SWR but in a larger form called LWR, Bluetooth is always improving this issue. Cellphones are worse due to the fact that it is using a Higher Frequency of Wavelength. So in all the percentag rate of you getting sick from Bluetooth is VERY slim, but if you never take them off let's say and glue them to your head literally for days and years you could damage your DNA or RNA to the cellular level, which in turn can cause mutations in cells that reproduce new cells, causing cancer. but you should be more worried about the Nuclear Power Plants because a little bit of that and you will be dead from lethal Radiation. In all Enjoy those Bluetooth headphones :) The old tube TV’s emitted large amounts of x rays and some gamma. Life is short and don't let things tie you down.

This is a classic case of “internet based science”, which is diametrically opposed to “evidence based science”.  In IBS you make something up and dare people to prove that it isn’t true.  In EBS you study something or other.  Try to figure out how it works and maybe you try to extend the positive principles you have learned to ideas that may not be immediately obvious.  The problem with IBS is the old problem of having to prove a negative.  It is widely believed that you can’t logically prove a negative, so probably headphones will give YOU cancer.  Just you.  Not me.  In EBS, otherwise known as “real science”, assertions are positive and provable.  So identify the set of people who have the object you’re worried about.  Now identify the people who have the condition you are worried about.  How much overlap is there?  I suspect that the overlap here between owners of a particular head phone and any form of cancer, would be small, but I’m too lazy to do the work. :)

Having of the interest lately raised in the press regarding mobile phone usage & a possible connect to human brain cancers or even tumors , I experienced it essential to make clear a few things for Headphones end users . First of all , allow me to begin by declaring that I in no way declare to be a specialist on Any specific health matters in any respect . My field of skill is within Corded , Wireless & Bluetooth headphones . The following was merely gleaned from a recently available post showing up on CNN & Larry King , showcasing a few of the world’s most famous neurologists & research workers with this matter . You will discover three various kinds of “Cordless” gadgets that I am going to be speaking about here : Mobile phones , Bluetooth headphones , & Wireless headsets . Do not get confused between Bluetooth & Wireless headphones ; Bluetooth by the majority of accounts deals a variety of relating to 33’ ( Certain more recent technological innovation provides 100’ to 200’ ) & the audio quality is substantially inferior with that of a “Wireless” headphones ( 300’ to 400’ ) that is equivalent to or even more than a wireless phone in the quality ( Plantronics CS540 Wireless Headset for example ) . And to read more about health matters that can cause by Wireless Headphones check on this article: How to Prevent Damage To Ears When Using Wireless Headphones

I switched over to Bluetooth a few weeks ago, and use headphones over my hearing aid at work. Headphones in general can cause pressure points on the ear, especially over a hearing aid. Ones ears can be sensitive to pressure points, and possible infections. The ear canal can be highly sensitive, and sound waves can aggravate tissue. It may not be cancer, but rather an abrasion, or infection. Get your ear checked. Experiment with other types of headphones for a few weeks and see if the pain goes away. The ear isn’t really designed for headphones. Volume, bass, pitch directed at the eardrum can cause damage at the right levels. See an ear doctor specifically to get your ear checked.

I don't think there's been peer-reviewed studies yet, which link beyond reasonable doubt, Bluetooth transmission to cancer (brain or other). However, as with any new technology, it's probably wise to be on the cautious side of things. In your case, with 8 hours per night of radiation right up against your skull, I reckon your parents have every right to be concerned: it's just too-recent a technology to know for sure, but logic would indicate that it's probably very bad for you. You've perhaps seen these thermoscans of a skull when a cellphone is held against the ear? I don't think millions of years of evolution have prepared our body for this kind of treatment. Bluetooth is just a more recent method of transmitting digital data over radio waves, and I imagine it has the same shortcomings.

The wireless headphone are typically receive only devices unless they also incorporate a microphone in each ear piece. In that case, it may be possible to connect to your PC or smartphone via Bluetooth to emulate the old style headset/microphone combination that used a special phono jack typically supplied on the older smartphones and PCs. The signal levels for a Bluetooth connection are very low so the range is extremely limited. (10 meters maximum). It is highly unlikely that the power being transmitted could ever cause a brain tumor. These wireless headphone run off of rechargeable batteries so they would not run very long on a full charge if they radiated anywhere near power levels that could remotely cause a brain tumor.

There is not enough evidence to definitively say that wireless headphones are dangerous or that they cause cancer. The radiofrequency from wireless Bluetooth earbuds has a lower intensity and radiation emissions or electromagnetic fields or simply EMF, which may not be strong enough to cause tumor growth that results in cancer. Ultimately, when it comes to wireless headphones, its dangers aren’t all that clear. Despite extremely low frequency EMF being possibly carcinogenic to humans, researchers have still not observed a direct connection. Bluetooth headphones specifically have their power density exposures that is 10 to 400 times lower than those of cell phones. It may be near impossible to completely avoid radiation these days, but we can all take a few steps to reduce the amount we’re exposed to on a regular basis.

So far, there hasn’t been much data to suggest that Bluetooth headphones cause cancer. Although Bluetooth headphones do emit radiation, radiation would be much less than a cell phone. I have read an article in Arkartech about "Do Wireless Bluetooth Headphones Cause Cancer?", this article said: The U.S. National Toxicology suggests that High radiation levels increase the risk of getting gliomas (malignant brain tumors) and schwannoma (benign nervous system tumor). In my opinion, this conclusion based on the high radiation, while the radiation of the Bluetooth headset is relatively low, as long as the appropriate and reasonable use of Bluetooth headsets will have a very low probability of brain cancer, I think that there is no need to worry too much. About more Bluetooth headphones problem, you can read this article about Do Wireless Bluetooth Headphones Cause Cancer which I mentioned above. Hope this helps!

No. Wireless headphones receive wireless signals they don't transmit them. Unless they are Bluetooth and even then the quantity of data they transmit back is tiny.Short range wireless transmissions use very low power. Wireless headphone transmitters usually have less power than your WiFi router.Wireless signals cannot cause cancer, they don't have sufficient energy to ionise DNA.

No. There is no scientific rationale to believe that Bluetooth earphones would cause brain cancer. I’m not sure where you heard this, but it is quite obviously false. In fact, the opposite is recommended by by the CDC (Center for Disease Control), the FDA (Food and Drug Administration), and the American Cancer Society-all say that Bluetooth headphones prevent radiation from entering the brain, lowering your chances of brain cancer.

Wireless headphones and earbuds are emitting wireless radiofrequency radiation very close to your brain, and that can create oxidative stress and inflammation by creating hydroxyl and peroxinitrite free radicals. Chronic inflammation leads to chronic illness and mitochondrial disfunction. That in the extreme case can lead to things like cancer and MS, ALS, Alzheimers, etc.

No, whatever radiation given off from the internal radio is so minute that in-order for someone to notice any affects, you’ll have to wear/use that device 24/7/365 for about four or five lifetimes before a hint of damage could be noticed. We are surrounded by radio based radiation on a daily basis and not a single case of cancer has been caused by it. Cell Phones and Cancer Risk

But if you’re asking about radio-frequency radiation from the Bluetooth part, no.

In my perspective, anything can be blamed to cause cancer if you happened to have it.. It is more like a knee jerk reactions.. Bluetooth energies are very tiny as compared to the energy being radiated by a cellphone, especially if the cellphone has a weak signal receiver reception. Comparatively, WiFi signals are in my view which are radiating more energy power wise… Which means that WiFi signals are more likely to be reasonable cancer causing energy if you are looking for any justifiable causes of brain cancer..

No. For any electronic device to cause cancer it would have to emit ionizing radiation. This would mean the the radiation must be powerful enough to knock an electron out of an atom. This doesn’t happen until the energy gets above the energy of the blue and into the energy of very high Ultraviolet. Bluetooth and other radio frequencies do not have as much energy as the flashlight. If you would feel safe to shine a flashlight at your head for 24/7 then you can feel safe to wear a Bluetooth ear plugs 24/7. I do.

Yes, Bluetooth radiation is a thing—but that doesn't mean you should freak out about your wireless earbuds. I recommend keeping phones away from the body when they’re not in use, sleeping with phones away from the bed, and using headsets or headphones to conduct phone calls. They point out that Bluetooth devices also emit radiation (at lower levels than cell phones), and that wireless devices should be removed from the head and ears when not in use.
